relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
And today we're visiting with Oliver Retzloff.
we're so excited to have this opportunity to visit with you in your flower garden, your flower farm, wild nectar farm.
Oliver Retzloff was born and raised in Boulder County, Colorado.
He grew up on an organic farm where his family grew vegetables and fruit and raised chickens, rabbits and horses.
He graduated from SAE Expression College in California.

relationships.evidence_text: He and his husband, Eric, moved to the farmstead in 2013.
have been stewards of the land.
working to rehabilitate, rebuild and regenerate the diverse microcosmic ecosystem.
Their focus is regenerative agriculture.
utilizing organic and biodynamic methods.

and hogs for meat.
and also keep honey bees.

a lot of gathering and celebrating potlucks, etc.

relationships.evidence_text: So most of our business is wholesale. We sell mostly to local florists and then we have a few accounts where we do weekly arrangements for a couple businesses.
I'd say a half dozen weddings in a season that are very specific and tailored towards kind of our aesthetic.
there is a great group the Colorado flower collective which is down I think they're in Arvada now.
there is a little bit of profit share there with the collective.
they could take all their flowers down to the collective once a week.
designers and florists and other wholesalers can shop from the collective.
I grew up my early years around the Seattle area.
I'm most picturing something kind of like a pikes place market.
not everybody grows everything and not everybody grows the same thing.
you're growing a lot of varieties of flowers including dollos, zinnias, cosmos, marigolds and snap dragons.
I tend to think of them as like the unicorn of flowers.
there's about 42 different varieties of dollos species of dollos I guess you could say.
over 50,000 cultivars which is insane when you think about it.

in our zone which I think is 5B we they're not perennial here.
once the frost comes we have to dig up all the tubers.

in terms of selling dollos they're a high dollar flower.

that's wholesale.
this is a cash crop.
